titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Winthrop Family Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Contains letters from various people, including colonial officials and legislators, to Fitz-John Winthrop, John Winthrop (1588-1649), John Winthrop (1606-1676), and John Winthrop (1681-1747); one letter from Fitz-John Winthrop to Joseph Dudley; and various other documents, including Abraham Pierson's elegy on Theophilus Eaton, and a brief diary by John Winthrop (1606-1676).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Winthrop Family Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Winthrop Family Papers. General Collection of Books and Manuscripts. Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced from a previously existing card set in the Manuscripts Catalog, or from another inventory. All pertinent bibliographical information has been retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Winthrop Family Papers are organized in two series: I. Correspondence and II. Other Papers . The papers span the dates 1635-1720, with the bulk of the material dating from between 1670 and 1710.

Series I, Correspondence
, is arranged in three subseries: Incoming Letters, Outgoing Letters, and Third Party Letters. Letters within each subseries are arranged alphabetically by recipient and then by correspondent.

The letters to Fitz-John Winthrop contain information on his particpation in the government of Sir Edmund Andros and his subsequent negotiations in London for the restoration of the colony's charter; Connecticut's border disputes with the colonies of Rhode Island and New York; and Indian conflicts and alliances. Letters to John Winthrop (1588-1649) include two from Roger Williams concerning disputes among Narragansett sachems and fights against the "Dutch Indians;" a June, 1636 letter from Jonathan Brewster discussing the war plans of the Pequots and their distrust of the English; a request for assistance from Lion Gardiner; and letters asking for medical advice and inquiring about conditions of settlement in Connecticut. The correspondence of John Winthrop (1681-1747) contains a request for a description of moose from Cotton Mather and a letter from Thomas Buckingham concerning the founding of the Collegiate School, which is also the subject of a third-party letter from Buckingham to James Fitch.

Series II, Other Papers
, is arranged alphabetically by author and includes a "Note of payments disbursed to my son, for the affair of Connecticut" and a travel pass for the Niantic sachem Ninigret, both in the hand of John Winthrop (1588-1649). A contract by John Winthrop (1681-1747) authorizes his agents to purchase a Carbuncle stone from the Indians, if one can be located.

scopecontent.p: Concerning a petition from Long Island; Dutch fleet.

ALS from Rev. James Pierpont (1660-1714), New Haven

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Encouragement to Winthrop in his negotiations for "our liberties" in London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dated 1697/8 Feb 25 and 1703 Nov 8.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: News of the struggle over the Spanish Succession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Border dispute with Massachusetts over New Roxbury (Woodstock).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rejoicing at Winthrop's return from England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning disputed Narragansett territory and the mission of a Rhode Island delegate to London.

scopecontent.p: Also signed by Stephen Goodyear.

ALS from Jonathan Brewster (d. 1659), Plymouth House

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning the plans of the Pequots and their "mistrust that the English will shortly come agt. them."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: For leave to transport a small load of Indian corn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: For medical advice.

ALS from Lion Gardiner (1599-1663), Isle of Wight

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Request for assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Thanks for his advice.

scopecontent.p: One written before her marriage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning settling with his family and operating a sawmill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1649 letter concerns disputes among various sachems and fighting with the "Dutch Indians."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dated 1649 Aug 25 and 1669 Aug 19.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Family news; medical advice sought.

ALS from Rev. Thomas Buckingham (1646-1709), Saybrook

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning the founding of the Collegiate School (later Yale).

did.unittitle: ALS from Rev. Dr. Cotton Mather (1663-1728), Boston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Requesting a description of moose [for the Royal Society?].

did.unittitle: ALS from Rev. John Walton (1694-1764), Yale College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Offers a copy of his elegy for Governor [Joseph] Dudley.

did.unittitle: Copy of letter to Gov. Joseph Dudley (1647-1720), New London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Concerning the "unreasonable" request for men and supplies to fight the French and Indians in Hampshire; counteroffer of two hundred men. Remonstrates against Dudley's complaint to the Crown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On progress of the Collegiate School (later Yale College).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: For help from the Governor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Rejecting a request that the Governor travel [to London?].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Leaf addressed to "The Hon.ble Robert Treat, Governor" but letter possibly not to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Docketed: "their opinion upon reading the Agents letter."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Also signed by Joseph Curtiss and Peter Burr.

Agreement with J. Smith and J. Gallup, Plainfield

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Advancing Smith and Gallup funds to purchase the "Carbuncle and so much talkt of Shining Stone" from the Indians.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Docket by Winthrop noting that the funds were all returned to him.
